column4: We visited the Cave and Basin in late March. We took advantage of the Canada 150 free access. The cave was beautiful and it was very neat to see the natural hot spring in the cave and outside the cave in the basin. The other hot springs that we visited in Banff are just swimming pools filled with the spring...
It is in the town area a popular site for tourist. Before you go there make sure you first go to the Banff Information Center and ask if it is opened.
Fantastic history of how evolved and found. Sulphur smell and cave like setting. Fantastic job at closing in pool and making open area for banquets, weddings, etc.

Another National Historic Site I visited, taking advantage of the free entry to all National Historic Sites in 2017, on the occasion of 150 years of Canada. I strongly recommend the Discovery Tour, about 45 min, which takes you through the key spots of the site, and the knowledgeable engaging guide explains the history of the place. After taking the...

The cave, historic springs facilities, and the boardwalk trail were a lot more interesting than I imagined. We spent a couple hours exploring. Don't miss the movie upstairs on the history. It's well done. The big screen National Park movie is hard to see in the main hall. Well worth walking up to the spring above the cave. It was...
This was so amazing went there twice. This was the first Federal Park site in all of Canada. Lots of history, excellent knowledgeable staff.
It was neat to read on the history of the Cave and Basin. We went while it was free for the 150 year celebration. I don't think I would pay to see this otherwise.

I brought my young daughter here, and she loved the cave pool, as well as looking for the tiny Banff Springs snails in the basin pool.I think it is worth a visit, especially with children. I visited the first time when I was a child myself. However, we visited in the winter this time, and I prefer the site...
it was boring and the cave/ basin was tiny and not worth the trip. Not worth the cost for entrance. Save your money do something else.
This year for the 150th anniversary of Canada one has free access to some of the Park sites. This is one of the free sites.
We went cross country skiing and really enjoyed it. People are also hiking. The scenery is beautiful.

Imagine being the men that found these hot springs and caves coming out of the ground! We do this area during the winter time when no one else is around and hike the trails. It is so incredibly peaceful. The views are astounding and the history will humble you. This is a must see and do especially in the winter...
A great place to learn a bit of history. We were pleasantly surprised and glad we spent an hour exploring.
Very interesting, make sure you explore the outside area and the hot springs to the rear of the building

While in Banff, suggest you visit Cave and Basin. It provides a historical perspective of the area which is quite interesting. We were there in winter and had the place to ourselves. There's a nicely done museum and the actual hot spring that was discovered years ago. One could easily spend half a day here reading museum material and watching...
The place is great for families,couples,solo. Canadas 150 birthday so the place is free. you can spend an hour or more here. There is stairs and it was really icy so take your time.
Not too impressive. Doesn't worth to pay to visit the Cave and surrounded areas. I would rather go somewhere else if time is objective.

Good spot if you have a few free hours. Really neat to see natural hot springs in a more natural setting. Was free when we visited with Canada 150. Close to town. Worth seeing the first ever national park and the history of the Park service!

Very informative about the history of Banff National Park. Lots of pictures and displays showing original hot springs. Beware of strong sulfur smell from hot springs. But it is certainly beautiful caves
I wasn't expecting too much from this pit stop and it didn't surprise me or disappoint me. Glad I went but probably wouldn't go again when I eventually return to the incredible town of Banff!!!

great for families wanting to know the history behind the springs-static displays with pictures and a description of how the hot springs were found and brought a vibrancy to the area for years to come. Interesting to know what is behind the springs. Make sure to visit before taking in the soothing waters. Great for all ages and accessible as...

I'm not much for history so I wasn't that impressed with this place. If you have a discovery pass use it to see this place but I personally wouldn't pay full price to get in. When you first get there you have to walk up this slope that is far from the parking lot. There are two basins with one...

This is the birth place of Canadian Parks. It's a fabulously done trip into the past. Today, we took one of the trails and enjoyed the amazing quiet if the forest ending at a frozen falls and Sundance Canyon. Very Family Friendly.

This little hot spring is where Parks Canada started a century ago. It's worth a visit if you're into natural things. The extremely rare Banff Park Snail can easily be seen in the sulphur algae floating in the hot spring . This is the only place in the world where this snail lives.
Great gift shop and a nice walk from town to get here. Free with your National Park pass for 2017. Imagine what is was like in the 1800's to stumble upon this hot spring.

Nothing exciting but you get to see the original hot spring as viewed by the pioneers. The park has done a great job in preserving the past. It's like stepping through a time portal, we'll preserved in it's natural splendor. Lots of signage advising you not to dip your hands in the water because it can disrupt the ecosystem. Unfortunately,...

Been here a couple times, lots to see and lots of walking if you take an hour go through everything. Since the renovations in 2013 there is a lot here now, the cave itself, indoor exhibits, outdoor exhibits, and the walkways in the woods above the facility. Well worth the visit for a little Bannf history you probably didn't know...

This historical site in Banff is very picturesque in winter. We've been here before in the summers walking the trails and always enjoyed it. But, this time it was much more interesting to see with the snow on the mountains and on the trees next to the hot spring. It was magical outside even though the temperature was at -27...

Great presentation, fun and informative, an excellent way to learn about Banff. The cave is unique. The whole visit does not take too long, probably between 1 and 2 hours you can see everything. Then go for a walk and don't miss the display about the war prisoners. For Canadians and non-Canadians, a bit of history that is rarely told.

This is a good place if you want to know about history of Banff. There is a natural hot spring here, but not open for visitors any more. One can only see it from outside. Lots of good insights about Banff history. But again its good only for those who are interested to know about it, else can be skipped.

This was good to learn the history and the tv screens were massive. The cave was unique and the sulfar was very strong. Great price. Nice to visit but small and not as big as I'd hoped done in under 30mins.

We truly enjoyed the history aspect of this site. We tried to imagine what it must have been like to get lowered into the hot spring by rope - before the pool and the tunnel. I wish the pool was still operating.
Hiked the "free" portion of the trail with my son. Beautiful scenery and the history behind the site is very interesting. Planning on going into the "admission" required portion next time.

Visited here a couple months ago on our way to do the Sundance trail. Found it very informative and appropriately priced, definitely a place to visit if you want to learn more about the history of Banff. The cave is also very interesting to walk in and look at, just be aware of the strong smell of Sulphur. Also make...

We arrived very late and had no time to investigate inside the museum and little time to see the (admittedly very small) cave. However, the cave, the formation of it and even the smell, as well as the accompanying information are interesting (just don't expect a huge or showy attraction). Outside there are some (limited) interpretive displays -- there may...
We were expecting maybe more. It was disappointing to see the cave was the size of our kitchen and living room! Little walk outside but could have gone without!

Initially I planned to take the family here on our trip because I thought it would be a great historical experience. It ended being a very hot day and we had to park so far away because it was very busy. The walk up to the entrance was all uphill (not a big deal but again it was very hot)....

Very cool history and springs...that you aren't allowed to touch. Maybe they should close earlier in the fall because they were not prepared for the overnight snow with our group coming in. Apparently we hadn't paid for the inside tour as well as the outside, so they pushed us out. No other guests/tourists waiting before 11 am opening, and no...

Just recently visited the Cave and Basin for the first time this summer, I'm always delighted with the changes being made. I find that for the price of admission the Cave and Basin is a great value, the cave is beautiful and the entire experience is educational and fun!

It was interesting to learn of the discovery of the original hot springs and their preservation, which went on to become Canada's first National Park. The site has enough to occupy one for several hours if you read all the signage, watch the video, visit the cave, climb up to the top of the old bathhouse building to enjoy the...
Wonderful hiking experience to see the historic site and to see the sulphur springs high above the valley.

I loved my visit to Cave & Basin! I'm really not a fan of caves, but I enjoyed the one here, probably because it could be argued that it wasn't a "real" cave thanks to the skylight. Then I wandered into the Story Hall where I must have spent at least an hour watching the video and checking out the...

We walked the marsh loop and found ourselves at the Cave & Basin WW1 exhibit. We had no idea that there were internment camps in Banff and the interesting history behind them. Not only is Banff a beautiful tourist destination, there is a lot of rich history there! A must see.

Very good interpretive center. Did you know your Parks Pass allows you to visit for free?? Good film and If you have time, take your photo at one of the free photo stations and email to your family and friends.

We loved this visit to this unexpected site. We knew nothing of it but came across it after our loop walk. We found the cave and Spring really interesting. We learnt about the springs and original baths, walked up to where the spring originated and were interested in the information about the endangered snail. A surprising gem.
So worth the time just to take in the beauty of mountains of Banff while soaking up the heat of the hot spring. Very uplifting time

Beautiful Historic Site that should not be missed. People complaining about the smell are exaggerating. There is a slight sulfur/egg smell in the Cave but not enough that you cannot enjoy the site. The attraction is more than just the cave and there are walking trails outside that will keep you occupied for more than an Hour.
Beautiful location. A great way to learn the story of the national parks and learn about Canada. Lots of great trails nearby.

We were hesitant to go here, thought it might be a money-grab.Were we ever wrong! Amazing display, complete with historical accounts of the formation of Canada's FIRST national park!The natural thermal spring is unique and in a cave, very cool!Great information regarding the conceptions of Banff, its' development, and its conservation. I would HIGHLY RECOMMEND.

This was a great way to experience a small piece if Canadian history. I was on crutches so the steps were a bit much for me, but there was a ramp should I have chose to use it. I've been to Yellowstone so this is far from as spectacular as that, but still worth the visit to learn about the...

The cave and the basin are beautiful. You can see the power of the heat under the earth at work. You can actually see the mineral deposits being laid down by the flowing water. There is also a pretty walk up to the source of the water. The only down side is the smell - they don't call it sulphur...

This is an interesting 'museum'. You can see a cave w natural hot springs and hike a short trail outside on the property and see some more springs. Interesting place to spend an hour at. Cheap entry also.

I walked from the town centre,very easy flattish walk,interesting historically and cheap entry.Enjoy the smell of sulphur and spend some time in the cave until your eyes adjust and you will notice the beautiful colour of the water and the hole in the roof.I spent a good half hour here.

Incredible site that explains the history of the area in terrific detail. It has incredible views and the trails make a fascinating walk. Just be prepared for the smell when in the cave, it can make some people feel nauseous, think that the 1st Nation people worked on the principle "kill or cure".

Read up on this before you go. Reasonably priced so if you aren't impressed you haven't spent much. We discovered this while we were in Banff. An interesting historical account of the hot springs discovered in the area.
An educational spot! Didn't know about the snail surviving only in the stinky sulfur waters! A nice hike around the facility!

The Cave and Basin Historic Site is a must do for anyone who is interested in History. It's a fascinating walk through the place where the town of Banff started. Sulphur Mountain has many tourist attractions but these mineral springs were the very first. The original cave where both the First Nations people and the 3 railroad workers used is...

The Cave and Basin was interesting, it was a small site but the cave was fascinating and the price was excellent at only $4.00 to get in. It was too bad that the pool is nonexistent and has been since 1993. The rest of the site was limited in displays but the views of the mountains were amazing. Definitely worth...

Fantastic place, lots of interesting information, and great views. Loved the springs, the walk , internment exhibit and settlers camp. Our son and us enjoyed the snakes and snails game too! Great views,
Has a nice little museum aspect, defiently worth visiting while in the Banff area. Gives you a look into the formation of the parks and as well as cave/hotsprings.
Stopped here on a beautiful fall day and enjoyed the different experiences at this site. Kids enjoyed it and it was easily accessible with the stroller. Also freeEntry with discovery pass.

There was a great exhibit about the history of national parks in Canada. It really shows you how recreation and conservation policies have changed over time. I also enjoyed learning and seeing the snails and fish that only live in those hot waters. The outside board walk was very pleasant.

Our family spent a fun afternoon at the cave and basin. Entry fee is only $3-4 so it's a deal. The actual cave area is not big and you don't need to spend a lot of time in there but they have an information area that you can spend quite a bit of time in. Some fun things to do...
This was a fun place to visit lots of historical information about the springs and makes a great short visit, the many trails in the area make for great family adventures.

An informative stop into a museum and the original cave and basin, the birthplace of the Canadian Parks system. We have an annual parks pass so were happy to discover that our admission was free when we presented our pass.
The historical site is pretty cool, and the cave is amazing. although it does smell like sulfur! It is too bad they had to close the pools years ago
It was neat to see a hot springs. It was very interesting to read the history and information about the hot springs.

Before the hiking trail begins, you can pay to get into the Cave and Basin museum but we wanted to enjoy the great outdoors.The Cave and Basin trail leads into the Marsh trail and if you wanted to go further, the Sundance Trail. Some parts were mucky because of the rain we had and they've split part of the...

Interesting information about the cave and basin and hot springs in general.Don't forget to take the stairs to the top of the building and the small trail above the building this is accessible from the outside of the building.There are walking trails nearby. Some trails would even be accessible with a stroller or wheelchair.

This was the first National Park in Canada's history. It is a smaller location, but also has access to many well maintained trails nearby to enjoy! It is very interesting to see where the original hot springs was located and how it operated. Also, the cobalt and sulfur infused in the rock underwater creates for some very fantastic color in...

We arrived in Banff late afternoon, and after dropping off our luggage walked to it. Interesting information, cave was small but perfectly formed, not too busy either. Staff were helpful as all Canadian s seem to be.

...The amount of people at the time we went was just totally insane! While we wanted to read all about the history, most people of a specific culture were just interested in taking photos and selfies and really didn't care much about the historical significance of the site.Go when it is quiet and you'll enjoy it way more!

It has good interpretation about the history of this historical site. Park staff was helpful to explain to us about the rare snails in the hot spring, which are found only in this area. There are trails as well, but we didn't have the time to go on any of them.

I was not sure what to expect but loved visiting this place. You learn about the history and see the past and future come together. We took the Marsh loop which had great views but as it was raining the day before, it was very muddy. There are also tons of horse poop so you have to watch out. With...
We found it to be very interesting historic site. The views from the upper deck were awesome. The employees who took us on the tour were great performers and added to the visit.
The outside boardwalks and trails offer chances to see unsual flora and fauna due to the effect of the hot springs outflow

My wife and I decided to drop in for a visit. There is quite a lot of parking and a bit of a walk to get into the main facility. There is a great story to take in and one loses him/herself a bit when in the cave/basin. This is best visited during quieter times. The staff at the center...
you get to see the beginning of the hot springs & how they were discovered & how the national parks of Canada began. very interesting

It was surreal to visit the cave and basin and definitely worth the visit. The facility provides great detail into the history and it's definitely an attraction that tells such an interesting story.There is much to read, wander through and watch on a screen - I felt like there was so much to take in if you really wanted...
This hot spring gave rise to the Canadian National Park movement. Originally it was a swimming pool and there are interesting exhibits from that era.

This was a real learning experience. It takes about 1 and a half hours to do the whole thing. Costs $7 per person. There are guided walks, but we choose not to take a tour. Not sure if tour costs extra. You get to see the very first hot spring that was discovered. The cave area is quite small and...

Staff at the Luxton Buffalo Nations Museum recommended the Cave and Basin -- or we probably wouldn't have visited it. There is an entry building, a walk through a low rough-hewn tunnel, and the sulphur spring basin -- with the hole above it. The was interesting but what was really interesting is that it is unlikely that the Banff area...

If you are into history, this is a must visit as it tells the history of the national park system in Canada.There are two hot springs to view and a boardwalk up the mountain to the start of the spring (no touching or swimming allowed).Admission is under $5 and the tour can be done in under an hour.

Great attraction that you must see if you are in Banff.You can dip your hand in the very warm water from the hot springs. There is a designated spot where you can do this. In the main basin where you can see the hot springs bubbling up to the surface there are endangered snails living there so you cannot...

We learned of this site after arriving in Banff. The walk to the hot springs was interesting, and the exhibits showing how Banff developed were interesting. It doesn't take long to visit. Though I didn't find it tha exceptional, it does provide a visitor with an unexpected historical aspect of the Banff area.

I wasn't expecting to like this, but I really did. Firstly, you get free entry with your Parks Pass - just show it at the till. If you visit make sure that you take the guided tour as it's really worth it. The cave is fantastic as long as you can put up with the hydrogen sulfide smell of rotten...
We decided to do this tour and quite liked it. It is well set out although some of it seems pretentious.

This place was the beginning of Banff. The hot springs here are really interesting. The museum with historical information really adds to the experience. It is less than 4 bucks to see it. It will take about one hour to get in a nice visit.

Surprise bonus while in Banff. Excellent displays on site. Great views. Loads of local history. Definitely worth the visit. Marsh trail is longer than it appears and views of the actual marsh are limited.

So let me understand this. National Park: Sulphur Mountain Open, Gondola Open, Sulphur Springs Open but Cave and Basin Closed? Huh?Ok, so maybe it's in print somewhere but seriously, access to a public washroom at the Cave & Basin is closed as well?OK, so we chose to walk the marsh loop. Extremely nice and saved this trip. We...

We got there just in time to join up with a tour group. Very fun enactors that made it interesting. Got to see the hole in the ground where they supposed went down and found the pool. We went into the cave and saw the pool. Would go again and spend a little more time exploring the area.

It is amazing site to visit to know a little of the history of the park. You can walk from the town if you like to walk but it is a little far. If you are not able to walk, go by car. Eassy parking facilities.

Just when we thought we had covered all of the historic sites/landmarks in Banff we happened upon the Cave & Basin Historic Site. We arrived just in time to join the guided tour. We found out that this site later became Canada's 1st National Park. The history behind it was very interesting especially with the period reenactments by the staff....

First time up there sept 17. If you go, and I highly recommend you do, take time to read the history and changes that have taken place.It looked like great fun when the pool existed.Show your annual park pass to visit at no charge. And plug your nose when you go in the cave....

Check out this great spot near the center of town. Be aware it is really smelly, it's a cave and natural hot springs, it's normal. Since you can't swim in it, try the Banff Hot springs up the road. Make sure to check out the nature trail behind the building.

It's nice to see the history of Banff National Park and see the Hot Spring. We also walked the trail around the marsh and the lake, early morning, around 8.00. It was beautiful with the upcoming sun and to see the steam coming up from the water.

Was not sure what to expect when we visited this attraction and was pleasantly surprised. Provides great information on the birth of the National Park system in Canada.Very informative and worth the visit

Interesting stop. The original Bath house is still there and available for viewing. Because of the continual warm water trickling out from the hillside there is some very interesting plants and animals in the are. This is the place where Europeans "discovered" the warm springs of the area.

This was really a fun trip even though we only had about an hour before the closed. Cute activities for the kids, the cave was fun to explore and we had great view from the top of the buildings. Nice interactive museum area with video.

Used out annual park pass to get free entry to this historic site. A perk of having the pass!!Loved it. Historical with lots of information, friendly staff, and short walks. Beautiful place. And you can get a beer and a snack!
Very glad we went to see this. A hot spring that runs into a cave...you can enter the cave and walk around. There is a movie to watch and info on the hot spring from its use years ago.

As part of a day in Banff we decided to walk from Bow falls to the cave and Basin. As we got there only about 30 mins before it closed we did not pay to go in but did all the free parts which actually are very interesting. We did the boardwalk to the source of the springs saw the...

It's just a small cave with a hot spring in it. The smell of Sulfer Di-oxide is very strong and drives you out quickly. There is little to see in the "museum" attached to this attraction. It's under $4.00 so it isn't a bad deal. You really won't miss anything if you don't goo.

Very smelly Cave - which isn't very much and pretty small. You will wonder why they bothered. The museum part and viewing areas are much better if you like reading lots of information plaques. Some interactive elements. Very pleasant staff and entry cost is small so not bad. Cafe and rest rooms and souvenirs of course. Perhaps if you are...
Beatiful cave but that's it - only that one cave. So you're done in about 5 mins. At least it's cheap (<5CAD).

There are far more interesting things to do in Banff than the Cave and Basin. The smell is just awful and made my husband feel sick! If you're here for only a couple of days, find another way to spend your time. Banff has so much to offer. You won't be missing out if you don't go to this attraction.

The cave and basin is full of interesting information. I'm not a huge fan of museum and historical places, but I found myself reading all the information that was listed and enjoying reading about it. This tells me that they have done a great job of keeping it interesting.

I LOVED Cave and Basin, maybe because of the history... Beware the cave has the classic "rotten eggs" sulfur odor. The water looks clean but you can't touch it. The building surrounding the cave is beautifully decorated with stained glass windows and exhibits about the cave. Inside the building over the cave there is a movie about the parks that...
A pleasant walk from Banff centre. Well presented exhibits that explain the history of the site and its significance in the history of Banff.

We visited the Cave and Basin National Historic Site on a rainy day that we were scheduled to hike Johnston Canyon. Since this was a backup activity we were not expecting to enjoy it as much as we did. We learned that this was the birthplace of Banff which was triggered by the discovery of hot sulphur springs by three...

Walked to the site from the town took about 20 minutes. Very well laid out establishment and we were at the right time for the guided tour. Young lady was well informed and pleasant to listen to. Strong Sulphur smell when in the cave and the top opening might put some people off but really part of the experience. Nice...

Seeing this place got such great reviews we decided to pay and go see it. We anticipated a beautiful cave to walk around in by the pictures we saw. Instead you walk into a tiny smelly cave that fits a few people. I appreciated the history of the place, but definitely not worth the time to go see it ....

We had a few hours to kill until we could check in to our hotel. So we went over to the Cave and Basin. Your park pass for your vehicle will get you in for free... make sure you sign the back of it first.They have done a lot of good work in restoring this site and its history....

I consider this one of the must do things for Banff if you are interested in the history and how things got started in Banff. With the Cave and Basin on top, this was a worthwhile visit. With a National Park Annual Pass it was a cheap visit.

Situated about a mile outside of town this unassuming museum offers a great afternoon out for only $3.75CAD each, compare this to some other attractions and it's almost a steal. After paying the entrance fee in the museum gift shop there is a short walk up to the museum proper. We were met by a couple of guides, who with...

We enjoyed learning about the first National Park in Canada. The free tour led by great Parks Canada staff was the best and most entertaining way to learn about the cave and basin and a little bit of Banff history.

To go back in history at the original location as wonderfully restored was great fun with our San Diego friends.Nice to see the other restoration work and historical reinactments.Well done Parks Canada.

Definateley a neat place to check out. Very inexpensive as well. There's a lot of history here and the cave is pretty cool to walk around in! You're sure to learn something stopping here and the hiking around is worth it too!

Don't know why it took me so long to visit, I was really missing out. The natural springs are beautiful, and there is a great boardwalk hike with great views. They do a very good job using the exhibits to explain the history and significance of the site as well.Hint, if you are looking for the snails, they are...

Yes, it is an area of natural hot springs.Yes, it was found by First Nations people.Yes, it was "discovered" by explorers.But really, good money to look at a small basin of sulpher- smelling water, and then walk though a man-made tunnel to look at another one.Walking down to the marsh is interesting, with the variety of...

This was a well designed museum allowing visitors to see the natural hot spring that was at the origin of Banff National Park. A tunnel takes the visitor to the interior of a round chamber with a blue pool at the bottom and a small opening to the sky at the top. This was a sacred place for first nations,...
We was able to walk here from our holiday. The staff are very helpful and friendly. Lots of information boards. Well worth a visiti

This is a very interesting site to visit. The Cave and Basin is considered the first site in Canada's National Park system. We've visited many times and its free for park permit holders. Also, there's a pricey but good cafe on site.
Very informative place. The hot springs found here is where the concept of National Parks started in Canada. Very nice boardwalk to take leisurely stroll.
It was very interesting than it was 20+ years ago. I remembered it much differently. Although, I do not remember it then, it is a very cool place to visit.

This is a very special place - the birthplace of Canada's National Parks. What a pleasant stop. Very well presented exhibits, excellent video, handy little snack bar and beautiful outdoor surroundings. And a must: the boardwalk down to the marsh area. Of all we visited in 5 days in Alberta, this just hit the spot.
Canada's very first National Park, and the largest in the world all started right here. A perfect model for conservation and management of natural history and precious resources.
Learn in the interactive museum, take a leisurely hike through the caves ending at the original hot springs. Keep a look out for the protected snails that call this water their home.
Historical place to visit well set out with historical features and facts Great show in the big hall on the Banff history of the cave and the site Well worth the visit

Rainy day in Banff on your vacation? No worries! It helps the trees and berries grow which feeds our wildlife. Use it as an excuse to head over to the Cave & Basin. Walk into the original cave (unaltered) as well as peep through the exact same opening those three CP Rail workers did. Enjoy the History Hall, interact with...
Learn about the history of national parks. Interactive. Go in cave, see spring, send an e-postcard, take a sort hike.
This is a wonderful view of the original steam bath. Extremely well displayed and explained. Nice way around the exhibits.

The hot springs themselves have high concentrations of Hydrogen Sulfide which means it smells of egg. The museum is quite interesting and is about the Natives and work camps in the area. It was the first national park which is well explained. If you are interested in snails then we'll worth the trip otherwise I wouldn't prioritise this on your...

This was a neat little historical site that was quite cheap to see. Although it's probably not a must see it is still historically interesting. Most of this site is indoors so if it's raining out it's something to do.

Found the walk above the site where you could see the hot water to be pretty and a nice walk but the actual site was expensive and full of tourists. I remember going there as a kid when you could still swim in the pools and that was a great memory. Just walking around the old site and reading the...

A nominal fee gives you a glimpse of the REAL hotsprings that got Banff going as a destination and boy do they smell bad! Cool to see and learn about but definitely stinky (naturally!). Good activity for an hour or so and fairly quiet area.

It was a nice distraction from the large Mountainous ranges to close the day at a low key cave with a small sulphur spring . It also has a small museum about the history of BANFF which is quite interesting . The highlight is the board walk to the river bank . It is a more relaxing retreat after a...
It's a good historic site with vey nice museum. I love the awesome view as well.The only thing that is not good is the smell . But overall worth the visit.!!
Interesting place to learn about the origin of the national parks, but main interest is a visit at the original source. Strange that the historical swimming pool was removed.

This location showcase the cave, and the basin if you are smell sensitive please stay off the cave it smell really bad. The hallway has three large projectors screen showing the historic fact of the site.
the start of it all...banff became a tourist centre because of these hotsprings. A little lacking in more thing to look at besides the springs au natural.

This is an nicely done historical site with a decent museum. The highlight though is a visit to the hot spring cave and the boardwalk through the hot springs and Basin out back. The signs along the way give a good explanation of the site. The smells are sulfurous, as expected, but the life forms growing in the hot springs...

We did this after visiting the gondola. It wasn't crowded at all, but there was still a small charge to get in. Nice little gift shop, but as usual lots of Made in China things for sale. We were only able to see one cave. It was nice but small . The smell of sulphur is really strong here, so...

This was an interesting place to visit and explore. I had hoped to take the longer several hour hike out of the site and explore further, but the gift shop had run out of bear spray and I was not about to go out on my own without it during bear season. If I'd waited until after lunch, the trails...
We enjoyed showing the kids the original cave that was discovered and was the beginning of the Banff Hot Springs

As a Canadian I was fascinated to learn about this spot and its history as the first national park. It's $4 to get in or free with an annual park pass - you won't get a ticket if you park in their lot and bring your hang tag up to the building - and you can move freely through various...

We took a quick trip to the historic site... there is a cave that you can go into and walk along a few boardwalk trails, both of which allows you to smell the strong sulphur smell that comes from the water feeding the hot springs. There is also a history of how the Canadian national parks began and evolved, which...

This is where the city of Banff started. Nicely done and the cave is worth the trip. Cost very reasonable at around $4 for seniors. If you do not want to walk you can get a taxi during week days and a free shuttle from town over weekends. Marshland walk worth the time.

Our kids (3 and 5) really enjoyed the cave. It was a very quick walk in and the cave itself is pretty small. We went in once and it was super crowded so we didn't stay inside long. Right before we left we decided to go in the cave one more time and there were only a couple people inside....
The Cave and Basin is a required stop for a first time visitor. The visit can be done quite quickly if you aren't interested in the museum-y story boards.

It was interesting, but not great. You go into a small cave containing a mineral springs, discovered years ago. There were the original buildings of a hot springs bath. The cave and springs were the first place preserved in the Canadian National Park system. I am sure it has a lot more meaning to Canadians than those from other countries.

We wen't here on a rainy day. We just visited the visitor centre and the cave. But there are also trails nearby that you can walk. The cave looked nice. The place smelled like sulphur. It was pretty quiet when we went there which was nice.

My wife and I visited this wonderful site where the Canadian National Parks were started years ago. The purpose of this write up is to explain if you need a special assist to see the Cave and Basin you can get it if you ask. I have a handicap car badge so when I entered the parking lot I drove...

This park is on a far end of Banff, you need to look for it. The gift shop and museum area close 5pm, which was ok because we wanted to walk the trails and do some bird watching. It was difficult to find some of the trails with very little signage. Finally after quite a hike, we did see some...
This place is an important visit to understand the culture and begginings of the park we all love so much.

We decided to stop here after a long morning of hiking. Staff was very nice and knowledgable. Lots of information to read about the cave, hot springs, and history of the National Parks. The actual hot springs pool is now covered but still there along with the bath house, fun to look at old pictures and memorabilia. We did a...
The baths are no longer open for swimming. However the history, very important to Banff, is quite informative. There is an Interesting photo/videoexhibit and a " short" living history experience.

This is the story of Parks Canada's history from this - their first park to today's numerous parks all over Canada. The story of the cave and its connections to the First Nation people is interesting. Be careful if you have a reaction to Sulphur, the rotten egg gas smell can be powerful. After viewing this amazing pool and take...

Great filled a rainy afternoon in Banff. History of Banff national park and information of a rare snail which lives in the sulphur springs in the cave. If you buy a yearly pass to drive in the national parks entrance is free. Yearly pass cheaper to buy if travelling for more than 3 days. Small cafe selling snacks.

Very helpful staff. Well laid out information in different locations on the site. Beautiful walk round the gafden. Unfortunately we did not have time to go on one of the longer walks. Satch out for soecial events held here

This site has lot of information for history buffs and nature lovers. The cave, museum, the replica of the native village, the springs and the nature trails are all very interesting and entertaining. Our kids had lot of fun roaming around the trails and the site.They also have a small food store where you can get sandwiches and coffee.
Cheap, informative and good when you've got nothing else to do. Very small and don't within 45mins. Nice but wouldn't return.

Lovely views, typical historic site, and be wary of the sulphur smell in the cave. The hike to the Canyon is really the hike to get to the starting point of Canyon hike. The first hike is paved and simple, the second is moderate level.
I really did not know what to expect. This is where the National Parks of Canada were started. The cave, exhibits, trails, and big screen movie were excellent. I would highly recommend this.

This place gives you such great info on the hot springs discovery. I am glad we went here before the springs. The history of the cave and basin is easily read and informational. A pretty walk around the area finishing with a cold drink on the upper outside viewing deck.

There are two parts to the Cave and Basin. The external area and boardwalk to the springs and the inner area with the cave itself and interpretive area. The entry is $3.90 and well worth it. Combine it with a walk to Sundance Canyon about 4km up the trail.
Canada's first national park was born here. I found the exhibit quite interesting. If you're in Banff, its worth the visit.

Our family went on the guided tour of the cave and basin which was a fun one hour walk around the site. Its fun for kids with a few live actors in character along the way. The kids get an activity book at the start and get a prize if they complete it at the end. Lots of interactive displays...

You can get in free if you purchased the discovery pass. The tour is fun and animated which makes it great for families. Besides the caves there are several hikes and trails to check out, but take bear spray as lots are feeding on berries this time of year. I plan to try the Sundance trail, but I was told...

So amazing to go through the history of the springs.. They had a scavenger hunt for the kids to do to keep them interested and each kid got a prize at the end.. I would definitely suggest to go for a visit. Only took about 1/2-45 mins to see it all.

I guess we should have read a little more about this attraction. We knew it was a historical site, but I was expecting more of a cave. It was a very small cave. We were disappointed. You walk 20 feet into a small cave and that's it, turn around and go out. The price is right though only about $4....

This is my first visit to this nice place , the view here is gorgeous, but the smell of the sulfur gas is very strong here , it is nice to take pictures here and write your review and get an email with your photo and your review or you can send it to your friends , visiting this place...

The history of the VERY small cave is extremely interesting and can be seen and enjoyed in about 10 minutes. It's free if you have the Parks Discovery Pass and worth it if you do. Otherwise you have to pay almost $4 to see it. We did the Marsh Loop hike afterwards and I would NOT recommend it. Not much...

Had we purchased a group pass, visit all 4 museums in the area at a price of C$20 per adult.This one was interesting, gave some local facts, got to see (and smell) the sulphur pools in, and out, of the caves. Was rather small area and stank of rotten eggs, but we were glad that we visited.

This is just a short walk out of town it has enough to be worthwhile visiting , the entrance ticket price is only a few dollars and is good value, the staff were helpful and had great knowledge of the venue .
Enjoyed the discovery tour with Jess as our guide. She made all the bits of history come alive from her canvas bag of tricks. Great for young kids as well.

I thought it was caves and basins i.e. several caaves and basins to see there, but there was only ONE cave - a small disappointment. I had seen pictures that gave me the impression it should be more to see
A great walking trail to see the hot mineral pools and read about the history. For a small fee it is worth it to go into the museum and see the "cave"

Well worth a visit. It is reasonably priced, and you can spend a lot or a little time at this historic site. A nice gift shop which is worth a browse - I managed to get a Parks Canada tshirt for $15, and some shirts for my nieces and nephews at $7.50 each. It is very informative, and offers a...

We stopped here thinking we would get an extensive tour of a cave, which we have enjoyed in other locations. However, we were surprised the "tour" consists of a short walk into a cave to see a pond at the end of a hallway. Boring.But then we came out of the tour and started heading up some stairs which...

Well worth a visit for some historic facts. Free if you have a Parks Visitors Card,so make sure you take it with you. Not as spectacular as I had hoped but a good half day attraction. Easily walked along the river from Banff
For the price, definitely a visit to make. It's the start of the national parks of Canada and the site make the discovery easy. The explanations are simple, clear and do not go too far.

We decided not to pay to go into the cave and see the bath but we found out after that it was quite inexpensive. We climbed the stairs and walked along the hot springs Boardwalk. Great views and walking through the greenery and checking out the natural springs was lovely.
Good place to understand the history of hot springs in Banff - but do not miss the boardwalk to mineral water springs - quite interesting and educative

the cave is very small.i expected some exploring caves and tunnels but it looks more of a basement with a pool. the exhibition is not that great either.the name would have made more sense if they didn't remove the basin!

Banff is located in one of the most beautiful areas in the world.The city itself is pleasant and very nice.The cave is a nice place but unless you really have nothing to do , go there.Otherwise feel free to skip the place.

A friend and I partook in one of the evening lantern tours into the cave. The cave itself is small, so don't be expecting anything too huge. There are "actors" that play out the history of how the cave was discovered and a short film afterwards showing how it played a major part in the creation of Canada's park systems....

We arranged for a private tour for our family reunion,and it was so much fun! They offer this tour twice a day without a reservation - check for times. They act out part of the history and give you lots of information about Canadian parks history. We spent about an hour here.

We expected to see more of the cave (but it was just one small cave). You do get an opportunity to read about the history and see some of the sulphur hot springs (you can't touch), but it was relatively small and there are many other beautiful things to see, especially if you are on limited time.
At 54years old we need a break from hiking even my twenty year old son has to have a down day . Funny,informitive and engaging guide.nice gift shop.stilltime to walk the shops in banff

This is a very historic area close to town. It is fascinating to see where the hot springs go out into the marsh down below, where the warm water is enjoyed by small fish, birds and other animals. It is a beautiful setting and well worth a short visit.
The cave and the basin are cool hot springs with lots of history, but you won't need to spend much time here - its a small space and there is not a lot, particularly if you are with kids.

The Cave an Basin is rated as a top tourist attraction in Banff, a must see. However, to be brutally honest this attraction has been massively over-hyped.The cave is tiny, info provided limited and the whole visit left us feeling a bit puzzled. Why this hot spring was so important to the history/people of Banff is still unanswered!However,...

It is really just a hot spring that is open to the public viewing but they have made it a fun place. There is an interactive book for the children to complete, movies in the main hall, multiple games for the children to play throughout, people in period costumes role playing, cafe. Well done, we spent about 2 hours here.

An historic spot in Banff, interesting for its unique fungus and snail symbiotic relationship. You don't need much time here. There is a tiny snack shop and historic, now filled in and closed , former hot spring fed swimming pool from the 20's.

We visited this after going up the gondola to Sulphur mountain and a visit to the hot baths. A good short trip with some nice walks along the boardwalk as well, which help make up for the cave view being very short
This was fascinating to see and learn about the Hot Springs History. It was also an amazing little hike.

We spent a lovely day exploring the caves and basin. The caves were interesting but too crowded for me. However, the walk up to the waterfall was spectacular. You can't take a bad photograph there because everything is gorgeous...keep your camera out and ready! The color of the river water was amazing!
We enjoy going to the Cave and Basin when we go to Banff, because you can take the Marsh walk which we really enjoy.

Save an hour in your day to visit the Cave and Basin to see the original springs and old bath house that started the development of Banff. We loved seeing the old photos of people in 40s and 50s bathing costumes enjoying the hot springs.

Although this site is the first national park in Canada, I found it to be a great disappointment. The cave is nothing like Carlsbad Caverns National Park in New Mexico. The cave contains a putrid smelling sulphur pool and nothing else. it is also very small. The stench of the horrible smelling pool made me sick to my stomach and...

This place is either interesting or boring depending on how you like it. Yes the history and the view is there but really not much to see here. A few pictures later, most people would probably get bored. If you don't have much time in town, it's ok to skip this one.Also you get in for free if you...

My husband and I visited the Cave and Basin National Historic Site on a recent visit to Banff. We parked (for free) and paid the <CAD 4.00/pp entry fee. We spent an hour or two exploring the indoor museum exhibits, seeing the actual cave and basin, and walking along the upper and lower boardwalks surrounding the facility (we elected not...

Went to the birthplace of Canada's parks for a night lantern tour.The tour is quite entertaining and a fun way to learn about the very first national park.It's kids' friendly but the lantern tour could be a little bit spooky for the little ones
The cave is amazing and a little on the nose but to learn where the water in the cave came from is very interesting. The history behind the snail is something that we all take for granted.

Very interesting cave with unique snails in the sulfurous waters. Interpretive boardwalk though the original site is well worth the visit. Suitable for a drizzly day as the walk is short and there is enough in the visitor center to entertain all ages for an hour or so.

As you will probably have a National Parks Pass (well worth the money for an annual pass) entry will be free. It explains the history of Canadian National Parks which started here plus there is the springs which smell of H2S (hence Sulphur Mountain)

My wife and I are all too familiar with sulfuric smells, but this cave takes the cake. I couldn't spend more than a minute in the actual cave, but that's about all you need anyway. It's nice, but unspectacular. The rest of the place is great. Interactive displays, a great multi-screen movie about the park, activity room for kids. It...

I can't review the tour or the inside yet, however walking along the raised walkway was beautiful. It's a little smelly, like sulfur, but beautiful. This would be an excellent outing for children of all ages

The Cave and basin offers a very interesting activity for young and old alike. If you have 1-2 hours its a great diversion from the sights of Banff. Don't miss the boardwalk that allows you to see a truly unique ecosystem found no where else in Canada. The hot water from the spring flows down the hillside to the wetlands...
very educational, clean and maintained. staff was very willing and helpful. good access for all including handicap and elderly

After reading a few reviews I really wasn't too keen on going but as hubby really wanted to go I went. We found it very good and informative. The view from the boardwalk was great. Overall if you have time in Banff go for a visit , it's actually quite interesting. It is suited to a non rainy day ....

Visited in June 2016 and I encourage people to visit this site. The guides are knowledgable and friendly, as well as informative of all areas of the exhibits. Although this was a couples visit, there were children and families in abundance and I was pleasantly surprised at how quiet the kids were as they listened to the guides and asked...

Haven't been here since I was a kid so I decided to bring my own kids to see. The cave is cool to see and enjoyed looking at the artifacts and watched the film. Great to see at least once. Disappointed to find out that the pool is no longer part of the experience as it was when I was...

As it was overcast and threatened rain, we went here.It far exceeded expectations. The cave is very small but the history of the place was fascinating and very well done. Guides gave informative interactive talks and we really enjoyed our visit. Great views all around too.

The birth place of tha Canadian National Park now has a proper tribute landmark with this interesting museum. You can see (and smell) the hot water in the cave where evreything began. Do not miss the interpretative path going to the hot spring! A must visit place!
If you visit Banff, you ought to visit the Cave and Basin! We love learning about the history of a place and for Banff, this is it!
Nice Exhibit. Informative. The pool does have quite an odor so if you are sensitive you may need to take a towel to breath through. There is a small fee to enter.

An interesting afternoon spent exploring the history of Cave and Basin. Smells awfully of rotten eggs (sulfur) but interesting to explore how it was discovered and how it had been used in the past, including as a large public bathhouse. We did this after a visit to the hot springs and was nice to get the full picture. Free entry...

The cave isn't much at all, but the other attractions make up for that. Nice trail to the Hot Springs and more attractions to see as well. Visitor center is interesting. Beautiful mountains surrounding the area.

I wasn't expecting how good the museum would be. We only went in because we have an Annual Parks Pass and it was free but I gladly would have paid the $4.A few nice interpretations on the site itself and the history behind it and then a wonderful history of Canada's park system with a stunning video show on...
Good for hikers and those who enjoy outside activities. The view is beautiful - lots of things to see.

We weren't sure what to expect, and the cave which is the origin of the hot springs was better than expected. The highlight was the free guided tour by the staff. It was interesting, fun, and filled with facts and delivered with clever humor to keep all ages interested. Big shout out to Ellie who led our tour.
An interesting, historic site where you can learn a little about the past. With several walks which provide an opportunity for bird/wildlife spotting, it's well worth taking the time to visit.

Easy 15 minute walk from the bus stop in Banff, the trail winds along the river and takes you to the first hot springs which are the origin of the park. Lovely walking tracks and the cave itself quite an interesting geological feature. Gives you a great sense of how this area was settled

The birthplace of Banff national park. The natural hot water spring has been well preserved as well as the microorganisms that feed from the spring. There are displays and information regarding the individuals who had discovered the area.There is also a very interesting museum on site regarding POW/ Internment camps that had existed in Canada during WWII from coast...

We left town early and had a lovely walk along the river, going past the stables and walking through the trees to get to the Cave & Basin area. It only cost a few dollars to get in so had a walk around the interactive area, and then went in the cave. We had it to ourselves so had some...

Walked from Banff to this attraction which was fine could have driven but needed the exerciseOne of the cheaper things we didCan spend as long as you want looking around. The cave is very smelly because of the sulphur smellLots of things to readLook out for the snails in the pondEnjoyEnough said
Nothing much to see at caves. We could not visit upper hot springs. It was a rainy day. Could have skipped this place
Nice to walk along the upper and lower boardwalks if its hot, cold, rainy, also the interpretive centre

Although this attraction is heavily promoted, there really isn't a lot there. A bit disappointing really. you can get in with your parks pass, so it passes an hour or so, but the scenery and other options are much more likeable

The cave is smaller than we had expected but we took some great pictures, outside the cave the displays were very informative, best part was our hike, the bow river is such a beautiful color. The mountain pictures we took are amazing. We didn't not run into anyone on our hike except the horseback riders. We have been in Alberta...

Learn the history of Banff, and view the mineral springs in the cave, but do NOT touch the water. They have found endangered specimens that must be protected. Swimming is now available at the Upper Hot Springs.
Nicely organized with lots of informative displays. Kids can do an Explorer program. Cave takes just a few minutes to visit. Try the do it yourself e-postcard at the end of the exhibit hall.

Got there an hour before closing and had plenty of time to explore and enjoy. Very informative. Friendly staff answered all our questions. A great value for your family to learn about the birthplace of Canada's National Parks.

We walked to the Cave and Basin National Historic Site on a day during our visit where we had nothing else planned. We were expecting a pleasant, if slightly boring, visit to a museum - what we found was much, much more than that.The Cave and Basin National Historic Site is the location that inspired every national park in...

We went to Cave & Basin because we were in Banff for a full week and had the time. If your time in the area is limited at all, this is one to skip. There were so many other great things we did in this area. After a 1-hour visit, I'm really not sure what the attraction was here.It...

Wanted to bring my daughter and show her where I used to swim. Was so awesome . Beautiful interpretive center. Daughter got to wear the 1800's bathing suit. So cool. Free with your annual park pass. So bring it up with you. Very cool to see

This is a nice visit to a local attraction with historical significance. It's not amazing, so don't hold your breath for a huge hot spring or wild entertainment, but for $3.90/person I can hardly complain. Definitely worth a visit if you're needing to kill some time.
A fascinating place to spend a morning learning about the development of the first National Park in Canada. Enthusiastic staff always willing to pass on their knowledge. Highly recommended.
This is a good 1-2 hour stop, admission was relatively cheap,just a few bucks each. It has good exhibits explaining origin of the park and the hot springs. Good stop worth,the hour or two.

We visited the Cave and Basin as it was why Banff (and the parks) now exist. There's a small exhibition - couldn't describe it as a museum - which has some interesting facts. The Cave itself is a short walk through a tunnel and has a short walk way at the front of the pool. The smell is pretty strong...
Glad I went it was very interesting. You can smell the sulphur along the beautiful walkway. Very well done...for sure

We set off walking from Banff to what we thought would be just a cave and parkland. How wrong we were! We joined the organised tour and had a great time. The tour guide was informative and funny, taking on different characters by changing hats and voices and really brought the history of the cave to life. It was interesting...
An interesting place, which is the home of National Parks. Lots to do and look at and a good historical account of how national parks came about.
Great exhibits and learning for the kiddos -- cool e-messages, a movie and the actual historic cave. Good price too. At the end the Park Ranger does an oath with them.

This is a nice little short stop in Banff. They have great exhibits showing Parks Canada's history, as well a the famous Cave and Basin with the hot springs. There is a great short movie that almost brings tears to your eyes it's so pretty.We arrived shortly before closing time so we unfortunately did not have enough time to...

I am shorter so no problem for me to walk through the short tunnel to the cave but really tall individuals may have troubles. I did not feel claustrophobic at all, maybe a dozen people could be in the actual cave itself at one time. You can smell the sulfur so you would take your photos and pretty go, though...

We went over to the cave and basin since it was included with our park pass. While it's history with respect to the park is interesting, it was basically a short walk into a cave to see a hot pool of water. Definitely not worth the walk from town.

A very modern structure surrounds this ancient cave all part of preserving it. The staff are well briefed and very enthusiastic in their role of interpreting and explaining. The displays are informative and interesting and the film displayed across four huge screens in the big hall of the former changing rooms was impressive. There was a facility for making and...

I really wanted to see the original underground pool which did not disappoint but was surprised by the interesting displays, the huge room on national parks, and the somewhat corny but very enjoyable and informative tour given twice a day. Don't let the low entrance fee make you think there is not much here. We ended up spending over two...

You can smell the sulphur as soon you get out of the car in the car park. The place has both free and paid activities. We didn't pay to enter the cave instead walked up through the stairs to the hot pool. Posters/boards describing the significance/history have been put up by Park Canada so the all the important information is...

If you're expecting a tour of a pretty cave, you'll be disappointed. There's just a short walk into an open area of the cave (where the cave opening comes in from the top), and you'll be done after a minute or so. But the grounds are very nice, as well as the historical displays. It's just a short drive from...

Free if you already have a Parks Pass, this is where National Parks in Canada began. For that reason alone it is worth visiting. The cave itself is quite amazing and there is interesting information on the history. However, it is quite a limited attraction and does not require a huge amount of time. Worth a visit, especially on a...
We enjoyed our time here as it is peaceful, relaxing with so much to see. We liked the cave but really enjoyed our walk to the marsh to see the fish and birds.
You can smell the sulpher as soon as you walk through the gates and it gets stronger the closer you are to the pool. The history is well presented on posters.
There are awesome caves to view and it is a great location for hiking. there is paved walkways or one can go off to the woods.
kind of disappointing you dont actually get to touch the hot water. Would have been neat to be able to do that but i understand they want to preserve everything.

Friends of ours recommended we visit the cave and basin which was the countries first national park.Entry to the facility will cost you $3.90 CAD for an adult and $3.40 CAD for a senior, which j think is quite reasonable.The site includes as tour of the cave which has a small but beautiful sulphur pool in it, followed...

This Historic site is well worth a visit at little cost.The quality of the presentations and the natural beauty of the site combine to make this a very interesting and worthwhile visit. You can pick up a Roam bus from Banff. We visited on Sunday and it proved to be a good decision.

column3: Cape Carteret, North Carolina, United States
column4: I was excited to visit this spot for photography mostly. We drove up there and upon arrival discover we have to pay to enter. The price is not outrageous, 3.90 CND per adult. But I was very let down once we entered. There is not much too see AT ALL..... the basin is pretty much a small swimming pool type...
No need to go to the cave.Just go to the cafe. You have a basin outside and it's free!!!! Watch the video.

An historically significant site for Canadians....it's the reason Banff began.Excellent staff who do well with explaining & discussing past events that led to the discovery & significance of the cave & basin.Our visit was include in a Banff Experience tour.Good old photographic display

We walk there as no public transport goes in on weekend and holiday... 45 minutes walk approximately...Opens only at 10H30 but worth the time spended... Nice little spot with so many beautiful thing to see... A must in your travel...

A receptionist at our hotel recommended we visit the Cave and Basin, we weren't sure what to expect but we had a few hours to kill and thought we would go along and I am so glad we did! If you can get past the smell, there is so much to learn about the history of the land and the...

We were walking along the Bow River and brought the marsh area and we decided to cut inland for our return to Banff and found the historic site . We were not disappointed. All staff are very knowledgeable and pleased to tell the story . If you not up to walking it's a short cheap trip out of town on...

It's a great adventure. We purchased the parks discovery pass so admission to Cave and Basin is included with that.Immediately my 3 year old saw the model of the large snail inside the exhibit. Naturally he really wanted to see a real one. One of the guides attempted to show him one in the outdoor viewing water. Kids loved...

We spent a couple of hours learning about the birth place of Canada's Notional Park system. It covers the cave that set everything off, how it eventually became a healthspa and now a parks museum. The walk up the boardwalk was particularly interesting showing the rock pools and how the water feeds the hot springs. During WW1 an internment...
My kids loved it and it was nice on the wallet too. The cave was nice and warm. The history was interesting to us.
Arrived late so we didn't have a lot of time to linger, but there's some great information here. I found the info about the snails particularly interesting.
had a great day today at the cave... was great weather.. nice people and a wonderful time! come check it out!

Very enjoyable historic site where you learn about the founding of the first Canadian National Park. Kids will like the underground cave but probably not the rest of the exhibits. Would be worth the trip for anyone interested in history. Only a couple of dollars admission.

This not a traditional caving sight. The cave has been built over with a tourist centre and the hot springs closed off to visitors. The walk into the cave is via smooth concrete tunnels to a hot spring. It has been done to protect the snail that lives in the water. There is a historical story line in the visitor...

Really great to see what has transpired over the past years. Remember going swimming in the pool as a kid. (over 40 years ago) The transformation to this tourist site is incredible. Our grandchildren enjoyed the many activities.
A bit underwhelming, but nice to see. We did the marsh loop hike, lots of horse dung along the way, very muddy.

We came here only because our park pass included admission to this site and we had some time to spare before heading up Banff Gondola for Alpine Lights. It was interesting. There were some exhibits, a brief film and the cave (quite small). Other than that, we didn't find anything else grabbing our attention. Honestly, I would have been disappointed...

WE came on a Monday and the exhibition hall was closed. Still plenty to see, and be sure to read the many informational placards, with historical photos. Walk on, past the exhibit/entranve building, towards the bath house. On the right, going downwards, is a lovely nature boardwalk that shows the various ecosystems made possible by the hot springs. If you...

We visited the Cave & Basin with our out of country grandsons & daughter on May 13/16. We thoroughly enjoyed learning about the History. Banff sprung up because of this. Very reasonably priced. ($3.90) ea. You'll detect the smell of H2S, but that's part of the experience. Don't let this slight smell deter you. Experiencing this natural mineral cave was...
We tried to go two times on this trip but it was closed both times! I'd suggest you call ahead to find out hours. Disappointed that we missed this opportunity.
We did not actually get access, no parking available which was surprising given it was mid week and early in May.
The cave is historic but be prepared for the pungent rotten eggs smell! There's a movie viewing hall and a chance to take photos and email them to yourself. The whole trip took less than an hour.
Interesting history but such a small cave. Our favorite part was the epostcard that we sent to our kids.

The views were great and if you're interested in the history of the site, this place is for you. I personally couldn't stay longer than 30 minutes because the smell is out of this world and if you're not interested in reading all of the history than it isn't very "fun".

We happened by this site and decided to visit. It was an interesting site. What's even more interesting were the facts that people used to bathe here. The hot spring was a little stinky, and the short walk to the cave was, well, worth the $3.80 they charge so it was okay.

Nice easy hiking. Learn a lot of history about Banff such as how the springs were found. How the parks were created and Canada's little know internment camps from World War One. Rangers were very informative. $3.90 to see the cave and main museum. They take and convert U.S. dollars and give change in Canadian. Interment camp musuem is free....

Was pretty cool. For the small entry fee of 4 dollars they charge it is worth the trip. The smell is out of this world tho if you try and lean over the outdoor basin and look for the snails. But that's part of the experience. Definitely lots to learn and enjoy there.
Was a little bit disappointed considering the cost. This place has a historic significance as well. The view of the mountains from the terrace of the building is stunning.
